action.action-desc: Mr. Wenstrup (for himself and Mrs. Lesko) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce

form.official-title: To prohibit the use of Federal funds to conduct or support certain gain-of-function research by a foreign adversary.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Foreign Adversary Gain-of-Function Research Prevention Act of 2023.

section.header: Prohibition on Federal funding for certain gain-of-function research by a foreign adversary

subsection.text: No Federal funds may be made available, whether directly or indirectly, or used by an entity, to conduct or support any gain-of-function research involving a potential pandemic pathogen by a foreign adversary, including—

paragraph.text: China, Russia, Iran, and North Korea; and

any other country the Secretary of State, in consultation with the Secretary of Defense, the Director of National Intelligence, or any other appropriate Federal official, determines to be a foreign adversary for the purposes of this section.

subsection.text: If the Secretary of State determines that an entity has violated subsection (a), such entity—

paragraph.text: for the 3-year period beginning on the date of such determination, may not receive any award or subaward of a grant, cooperative agreement, loan, or contract from the Department of Health and Human Services; and

for the 3-year period beginning on the day after the last day of the period described in paragraph (1), may not receive any award of a grant, cooperative agreement, loan, or contract from the Department of Health and Human Services unless the entity agrees, as a condition of receiving such award to—

subparagraph.text: give notice to the Congress before using such award to make any subaward; and
include in any such notice the intended recipient and purpose of the subaward.

paragraph.text: The term gain-of-function research means any research that may be reasonably anticipated to confer an attribute to a pathogen such that the pathogen would have enhanced pathogenicity or transmissibility in mammals, including the creation of a chimera.
The term potential pandemic pathogen means a pathogen that, as a result of any gain-of-function research—

subparagraph.text: is likely more transmissible or likely capable of wide and uncontrollable spread in human populations;
is likely more virulent or likely to cause modest or greater morbidity or mortality in humans; or
is likely to pose a severe threat to public health, the capacity of the public health systems to function, or national security.
